Lesson 3: Marketing and Planning

Image by Lawrence Crayton under Unsplash

During this part of the training, you will be working on marketing planning. An initial step is to conduct an Environmental Scan. The Environmental Scan template can be found here.

Instructions: Select the dropdown below to read about external marketing.

  • There are two major purposes of external marketing:
    • Connecting the program with prospective families.
    • Communicating the program’s brand and promoting its services.

Think back to your value proposition. You will definitely want to use your value proposition within your external marketing messages.

In order to begin understanding where to market externally, it’s important to understand the environment in which your program exists. To “scan” or assess the factors that may impact your program. Why is this important? Why perform an environmental scan?

Understanding the community that your program exists within will help you to tailor your services and communications to the needs of that community. It will also help you to understand any challenges that may hinder your program’s success.

So what environmental factors might be considered?

 Instructions: Select the dropdowns below to read about some of the examples.

  • Physical Location
    • Where is the program physically located?
    • Is it in a rural setting? Suburban? Urban?
    • Is there highway access nearby?
    • Is the program located inside of an office complex? Is it a separate facility?
  • Demographics of Community
    • What is the community like?
    • Is the population diverse, e.g., are other languages spoken?
    • What income level are most of the families in the area?
    • Contact local government offices for city and county demographics
    • See Kids Count State reports, data book.
  • Businesses Employing Prospective Families
    • What businesses are near you? An industrial park? Hospitals? A company that employs a large number of people in the community? What days and hours are they open? Are there shifts that work extra early? Late? On weekends? Could they be a source of referrals for your program? Could you offer a discount for families who work in that business? Providers can find this information at the Chamber of Commerce, Small Business Administration.
  • Other Child Care Options
    • It’s important to know what other child care options are in your area that families may be considering. What ages do they serve and what other services do they offer, e.g., transportation, child care scholarship accepted.
    • Not necessarily to compete but rather to identify what makes you unique and compelling for families to consider. Figure out what sets you apart. How do you differentiate yourself from other programs? Not all parents will choose your program, so it’s important for you to know where you fit and who your audience may be. Another point of comparison - How does your price compare to others?
    • The easiest way to find other child care programs in the area is to click on Find Programs on the Great Start to Quality website. You may also find program information on the child care licensing website.
    • Another source of information is the state market rate survey. CCDF regulations require states to conduct a market rate survey no more than two years before they submit their state plan. The survey collects data from providers (contributed voluntarily) and is publicly available. The market rate survey is available here
  • How formal does an environmental scan need to be?
    • It does not have to be a formal process, but it is useful to have a process in place so that you can be efficient when updating the information in future years and so that you have comparative data to reflect on.
  • How often should a program perform an environmental scan?
    • Ideally, programs would perform an environmental scan once per year in order to identify any changes that may impact their enrollment or be useful in making management decisions. At the very least, the scan should be reviewed each year and updated every two years.

Environment

Instructions: Think about the environment where the program is located. Identify aspects of the physical location and the demographics of the community that are relevant to marketing efforts. Next, determine what other options families have for child care in the area. Consider both center-based and family child care options in order to identify how your program fits within all child care options for families. Finally, identify whether there are any businesses in the community that may be resources for recruiting prospective families. Fill in the environmental scan section to the best of your ability right now, understanding that you may need to go back to your program and do more research, ask questions of others, etc. Think about the different elements that we just discussed as they relate to your program and write about each of them in their designated reflection box.
